docs.abstract: The Everything Store, which stocks more than 100 million items, is working to avoid disruptions in its supply chain.
docs.snippet: The Everything Store, which stocks more than 100 million items, is working to avoid disruptions in its supply chain.
docs.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — What if the Everything Store couldn’t sell everything because of disruptions from the coronavirus?

headline.main: Clicking Buy on Amazon? It’s Trying to Prevent a Coronavirus Caveat
headline.print_headline: You Clicked Buy on Amazon.  What if Your Order Is Stuck in China?

byline.original: By Karen Weise and Michael Corkery

docs.abstract: For his peak-TV coming-out party, the acting icon chooses a series that rolls together comic books, caper films, New York in the ’70s — and the Holocaust
docs.snippet: For his peak-TV coming-out party, the acting icon chooses a series that rolls together comic books, caper films, New York in the ’70s — and the Holocaust
docs.lead_paragraph: “Hunters,” a new series coming to Amazon Prime Video on Friday, offers various ways in. A lot of people will be excited because Jordan Peele helped bring it about. (He’s an executive producer.) That would have been me in 2015, post “Key and Peele”; not so much now, post “Twilight Zone” and “Us.”

headline.main: Review: Al Pacino and Nazis, in Amazon’s ‘Hunters’

docs.abstract: Who seems poised to benefit from social distancing? Big Tech.
docs.snippet: Who seems poised to benefit from social distancing? Big Tech.
docs.lead_paragraph: My relationship with social media? It’s complicated, to say the least.

headline.main: Facebook, Don’t Exploit Us in Our Time of Need

docs.abstract: We are more dependent on technology than ever. Can it handle the strain?
docs.snippet: We are more dependent on technology than ever. Can it handle the strain?
docs.lead_paragraph: Next week, Bits will be evolving into the On Tech With Shira Ovide newsletter. With a pandemic upon us, the significant effect that technology is having on our families, work, safety and sense of self is even more apparent. What is this reliance on technology doing to us and our communities — and is it good or bad? Shira will be your guide to this constantly changing world, during the coronavirus crisis and beyond.

headline.main: The Week in Tech: We’re Testing How Much the Internet Can Handle
headline.print_headline: The World Is Testing the Limits of the Internet

docs.abstract: This city is well ahead of the rest of the nation in the cycle of denial, panic, action.
docs.snippet: This city is well ahead of the rest of the nation in the cycle of denial, panic, action.
docs.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — You relish the little things here in Seattle: Toilet paper is back on some shelves, the hoarders sated for the moment. Instead of making vodka, distilleries are rolling out hand sanitizer. The dreaded daily number of new coronavirus cases shows that while the curve is not yet flat, the rate has gone both down and up on different days this week, carrying our hopes on the bumpy ride.

headline.main: Seattle Is Living Your Coronavirus Future
headline.print_headline: Seattle Might Be Living Your Coronavirus Future, if You Do the Right Thing

docs.abstract: Technology from Amazon, Apple, Google, IBM and Microsoft misidentified 35 percent of words from people who were black. White people fared much better.
docs.snippet: Technology from Amazon, Apple, Google, IBM and Microsoft misidentified 35 percent of words from people who were black. White people fared much better.
docs.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — With an iPhone, you can dictate a text message. Put Amazon’s Alexa on your coffee table, and you can request a song from across the room.

headline.main: There Is a Racial Divide in Speech-Recognition Systems, Researchers Say
headline.print_headline: When Data Lacks Diversity, Black Voices Are Muffled

headline.main: Even Without Amazon, Tech Could Keep Gaining Ground in New York
headline.print_headline: No Amazon? No Problem For New York Tech Boom

byline.original: By Ben Casselman, Keith Collins and Karl Russell

docs.abstract: Low-income workers seem to want Amazon in New York more than elites do. Amazon should figure out how to give them what they really need.
docs.snippet: Low-income workers seem to want Amazon in New York more than elites do. Amazon should figure out how to give them what they really need.
docs.lead_paragraph: [Update: Amazon said on Thursday that it was canceling plans to build a corporate campus in New York City.]

headline.main: Can a Progressive Case Be Made for a Amazon Campus in Queens?

docs.abstract: The region has its act together and knows what it is doing, officials said.
docs.snippet: The region has its act together and knows what it is doing, officials said.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — When Amazon canceled its plans to build an expansive corporate campus in New York City this week, officials more than 200 miles away in Northern Virginia decided to make a statement.

headline.main: Northern Virginia Is Keeping Amazon’s 25,000 Jobs, and Wants You to Know It
headline.print_headline: In Virginia and Tennessee, Leaders Are Happy With Their Amazon Deals

docs.abstract: The battle over Amazon’s New York plans resurfaced tensions among unions over how to deal with Uber, Airbnb and other emerging giants.
docs.snippet: The battle over Amazon’s New York plans resurfaced tensions among unions over how to deal with Uber, Airbnb and other emerging giants.
docs.lead_paragraph: It’s one of the most vexing challenges facing the labor movement: how to wield influence in an era increasingly dominated by technology giants that are often resistant to unions.

headline.main: Labor’s Hard Choice in Amazon Age: Play Along or Get Tough
headline.print_headline: Labor’s Tough Choice in Amazon Age: Play Along or Get Tough
